title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: While traditionally the health impacts of the biotic and abiotic components of indoor air have been assumed to be independent, recent studies indicate the opposite, highlighting the need for a systematic evaluation of their interactions to provide a holistic assessment of the health impacts of indoor air. In this study, we assessed the toxicological relationship between a commonly found indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and air fresheners, an emerging source of abiotic indoor air pollutants. We evaluated the cytotoxic effects of mold and two air fresheners (Brands A and B) on A549 cells and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. We also analyzed the chemical composition of the air fresheners using LC-MS. Our results show that both air fresheners were composed of several compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. Furthermore, the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions could influence the toxicological interactions. Overall, our study demonstrates the need for further research on these interactions for a comprehensive assessment of indoor air health impacts. The knowledge will also allow air freshener manufacturers to formulate products with minimal health impacts.
summary: This study assessed the toxicological interactions between a commonly found indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and two air fresheners (Brands A and B). The researchers evaluated the cell-damaging effects of mold and air fresheners on A549 cells and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. The chemical composition of the air fresheners was analyzed using Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry, revealing several compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. The results indicate that the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions can influence the toxicological interactions between the mold and air fresheners. The study highlights the need for further research on these interactions for a comprehensive assessment of indoor air health impacts. The findings also suggest that air freshener manufacturers could formulate products with minimal health impacts by considering the complex interactions between indoor biotic and abiotic components.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: This paper reports on a study that aimed to develop methods for screening and detecting mycotoxins in edible herbs using Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography-Tandem Mass Spectrometry and Fourier Transform Near-Infrared spectroscopy. The researchers analyzed a variety of edible herbs including basil, mint, and oregano for the presence of mycotoxins, specifically ochratoxin A, aflatoxins B1 and B2, fumonisin B1, and zearalenone. The study used ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry to quantify the levels of these mycotoxins in the herbs, and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy spectroscopy to rapidly detect and identify the mycotoxins.  The ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry method allowed for the detection of mycotoxins at concentrations as low as 0.5 micrograms per kilogram, while the Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy method enabled rapid detection and identification of the mycotoxins in a matter of seconds. The researchers also assessed the risk associated with consuming mycotoxin-contaminated edible herbs, finding that the levels of mycotoxins detected were within acceptable limits for human consumption.   the importance of monitoring mycotoxin levels in edible herbs and the potential for rapid detection using Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy spectroscopy. The findings demonstrate the effectiveness of ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry in quantifying mycotoxin levels in these herbs, and the risk assessment results suggest that the levels of mycotoxins detected are generally safe for human consumption. However, the study also underscores the need for continued monitoring and regulation of mycotoxin levels in edible herbs to ensure consumer safety. title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: This study examines the impact of hyperglycemic conditions on the response of colon cancer cells to two mycotoxins, alternariol and deoxynivalenol. in laboratory tests experiments were conducted on HT-29 colon cancer cells exposed to these toxins under normal glucose concentrations and under conditions of high glucose, simulating hyperglycemia. The results showed that alternariol caused a significant increase in the production of reactive oxygen species and induced programmed cell death in colon cancer cells under both normal and high glucose conditions. In contrast, deoxynivalenol reduced the spread of damage caused by alternariol under normal glucose conditions but had the opposite effect under high glucose conditions, where it enhanced the production of reactive oxygen species and cell membrane damage. The findings suggest that hyperglycemic conditions can modulate the cell-damaging effects of mycotoxins on colon cancer cells, with implications for the development of targeted therapeutic strategies.  This research highlights the complex interplay between environmental stressors, such as hyperglycemia, and the response of cancer cells to toxins like alternariol and deoxynivalenol. The same mycotoxins can have opposing effects on cancer cells under different glucose conditions, underscoring the need for a nuanced understanding of the material entanglements between human, environmental, and cellular systems.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes, threatening shelf life and food safety. In this study, a natural and eco-friendly strategy was developed using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO), extracted via optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), which achieved a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. GC-MS analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro, LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata (IC₅₀, 0.0718 μL/mL), while in vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed it significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). SEM, TEM, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed its safety. These findings support the application of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.
summary: This study investigated the antifungal properties of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata, a fungus causing postharvest diseases in tomatoes. The researchers developed a new extraction method, optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method, which yielded a higher quantity of LEO than conventional extraction methods. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis confirmed the consistent chemical composition of LEO across different production batches. In laboratory experiments, LEO showed potent antifungal activity against A. alternata, with an inhibitory concentration of 50% (IC₅₀) of 0.0718 microliters per milliliter. In experiments on tomato fruit, LEO substantially reduced the spread of damage caused by A. alternata and suppressed the accumulation of two mycotoxins: alternariol and tenuazonic acid (TeA). Scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, protein-level analysis, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted the cell membrane, interfered with energy production, and induced oxidative stress in the fungus, suggesting that LEO acts through multiple mechanisms to control fungal growth. Toxicity tests in mice confirmed that LEO is safe for use. These findings suggest that LEO could be a promising natural preservative for controlling postharvest diseases and mycotoxin accumulation in tomatoes. On one hand, LEO is a natural substance that can be used to control a fungal pathogen threatening food safety and shelf life. title: Role of T-2 toxin in the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin
source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: T-2 toxin is a secondary metabolite produced by different Fusarium species that causes serious problems in the poultry industry. It can damage several organ systems, mainly by inhibiting protein synthesis, and is also likely to induce oxidative stress in cells. In this study, the adverse effects of T-2 toxin were investigated in magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. Cultures were treated with 100, 500, and 1,000 nM T-2 toxin for 48 and 72 h. The metabolic activity of the cells was determined using CCK-8 assay. To investigate the changes in the oxidative homeostasis, the levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG were measured. To monitor immune response, the concentrations of IL-6 and 8 were determined. The metabolic activity of the cells decreased after the toxin treatments, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 h. Both MDA and HSP27 levels were significantly diminished by T-2 toxin after 48 h. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced by 72 h exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. summary: The study investigated the effects of T-2 toxin, a secondary metabolite produced by Fusarium species, on three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. The cultures were treated with three different concentrations of T-2 toxin (100, 500, and 1,000 nM) for two time periods (48 and 72 hours).  T-2 toxin reduced the metabolic activity of the cells, but this reduction was alleviated after 72 hours. The toxin also caused significant changes in the levels of oxidative stress markers, including malondialdehyde and heat shock protein 27, which were diminished after 48 hours. Additionally, the concentration of 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG), a marker of oxidative stress, was reduced after 72 hours exposure to the lowest concentration of T-2 toxin (100 nM). The study also found that T-2 toxin decreased the levels of interleukin-6 and interleukin-8, which are indicators of immune response, after 48 and 72 hours of exposure.   The capacity of T-2 toxin to induce oxidative stress and modulate immune function in chicken liver cells highlights its potential as a pathogen, causing harm to poultry and the poultry industry. However, the same toxin can also be used as a tool to study the mechanisms of oxidative homeostasis and immune response in avian species, revealing the complex interplay between cellular metabolism, oxidative stress, and immune function.

title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report

summary: This case report documents the severe skin damage that developed on a 36-year-old diabetic woman's left foot after 34 days of treatment with amphotericin B colloidal dispersion via a peripheral vein, which was switched to a central vein. The woman had been diagnosed with severe pulmonary mucormycosis. The nursing interventions implemented to manage the injury included the use of silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress. By day 155, the skin had fully healed with minimal residual pigmentation. This case report highlights the importance of careful medication administration and the role of bedside nurses in managing severe skin injuries caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation. The case also underscores the tension between the use of this medication as a resource for treating mucormycosis and the material consequences of its misuse, such as severe skin damage, which in turn requires resource-intensive management.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Invasive fungal diseases (IFDs) are common and often fatal in severe burn patients due to skin barrier loss and immune dysfunction. However, current definitions of invasive mold infections are poorly adapted to this population. This study evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria and their combinations in relation to clinical outcomes in burn patients. We conducted a retrospective cohort study of all patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023 with ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. Criteria included direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative PCR (qPCR) (Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium) on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and serum galactomannan. Among 276 patients, 489/6,184 samples were positive, including 281 skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) and 132 plasma specimens (qPCR). Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 was found in 93 patients (33.7%): Aspergillus (25.7%), Mucorales (10.9%), and Fusarium (9.8%). Twenty-seven patients (9.8%) had ≥2 criteria involving ≥2 mold types. Mortality rose with the number of positive criteria: 12.7% (0), 10.7% (1, 2), 27.3% (3, 4), and 46.7% (≥5) (P < 0.001). Plasma qPCR was positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement. Skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) combined with species-specific plasma qPCR enhance timely and reliable IFD diagnosis in burn patients. Mortality correlated with the number of positive criteria and coexistence of multiple mold species, underscoring the need for broad antifungal coverage and the value of multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment. summary: This study evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria for invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury. A retrospective cohort study of 276 patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023 was conducted, with a focus on patients with ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. The diagnostic criteria included direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative polymerase chain reaction for Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and serum galactomannan. Among the 276 patients, 489 out of 6,184 samples were positive, with Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium being the most common mold types detected. Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 was found in 93 patients (33.7%), and mortality rose with the number of positive criteria. The study found that plasma quantitative polymerase chain reaction was positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement. Skin biopsies combined with species-specific plasma quantitative polymerase chain reaction were found to enhance timely and reliable invasive fungal disease diagnosis in burn patients. The number of positive criteria and coexistence of multiple mold species correlated with mortality, underscoring the need for broad antifungal coverage and multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment.  The study highlights the duality of mold infections in burn patients, where the same organisms that can cause disease can also serve as indicators of immune dysfunction and skin barrier loss. The findings suggest that the capacity of mold species to adapt to and thrive in burn wounds can be both a threat and a resource, providing valuable diagnostic information that can inform treatment decisions.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), a potent mycotoxin frequently detected in improperly stored poultry feed, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin (CUR), a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa, exhibits strong antioxidant and anti‐inflammatory activities; however, its efficacy and mechanisms in mitigating AFB1‐induced hepatotoxicity in broilers remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary CUR supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to AFB1.
summary: This study investigated the effects of dietary curcumin supplementation on growth performance and liver health in broilers exposed to aflatoxin B1, a potent mycotoxin found in improperly stored poultry feed. Aflatoxin B1 induces oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin, a polyphenolic compound derived from the plant Curcuma longa, has been shown to possess antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. However, the efficacy of curcumin in mitigating aflatoxin B1-induced liver injury in broilers was not well understood. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary curcumin supplementation on growth performance and liver health in broilers exposed to aflatoxin B1.  The findings of this study suggest that dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1-induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers. The mechanisms underlying these effects may involve the activation of the Nrf2 pathway and the inhibition of the NLRP3 inflammasome. These results highlight the potential benefits of curcumin supplementation in reducing the adverse effects of aflatoxin B1 exposure in broilers. However, the complex interplay between curcumin, aflatoxin B1, and the Nrf2 and NLRP3 pathways in broilers remains a subject of further investigation. The Patchy Anthropocene lens reveals that the same compound that alleviates liver injury in broilers can also be a component of a broader assemblage of materials and organisms involved in the production and storage of poultry feed, highlighting the complex entanglements of human and nonhuman actors in the Anthropocene.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The World Health Organization has flagged the rise of drug resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus as a critical concern. Elevated mutation rates in this pathogen contribute to the rapid development of resistance, complicating treatment efforts. We conducted a study on the prevalence of azole resistance among clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022 and identified 34 cyp51A variants. To investigate the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes, we focused on novel, recent mutations and explored the effects of SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S and the combination of the mutations TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S on azole affinity and susceptibility. We created the three-dimensional protein model of the Cyp51A protein with azoles, and the mutation was introduced to the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain by the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique. Finally, in vitro susceptibility testing of A. fumigatus strains carrying the mutations was conducted to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The MICs of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type, with highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. Genotypes TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. In this study, we show that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene correlate to the structure–function relationship of in vitro phenotype.

They focused on four single nucleotide polymorphisms: L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S, and explored their effects on azole affinity and susceptibility when combined with the TR34 mutation. Using the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique, the researchers introduced these mutations into the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain and conducted in laboratory tests susceptibility testing. The study's findings suggest a correlation between molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene and the structure-function relationship of in laboratory tests phenotypes.  The researchers' use of CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing to introduce specific mutations into the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain illustrates the complex entanglement between genetic variation and material transformations in the context of drug resistance. The TR34-mediated resistance genetic profiles, which exhibit elevated minimum inhibitory concentrations to multiple azoles, highlight the duality of this pathogen as both a threat and a resource, with the potential to accumulate and adapt in response to external stresses.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The substantial increase in fungal diseases, the limited availability of antifungal drugs, and rising resistance to existing treatments highlight the urgent need for developing novel antifungal drugs. Natural products, known for their diverse bioactivities and unique structures, remain critical sources for antifungal drug discovery. In this study, we aimed to identify novel antifungal compounds from soil microbes and isolated a novel 28-membered polyene macrolide, compound 1 , from Kitasatospora melanogena . This compound demonstrated potent antifungal activity, with MICs of 4–16 μg/mL against Aspergillus fumigatus , Aspergillus flavus , Candida albicans , and Cryptococcus neoformans . Treatment with compound 1 led to significant growth reduction and disruption of the cell wall and membrane in A. fumigatus compared to the wild-type. To understand the underlying mechanism, we performed a transcriptomic analysis of A. fumigatus exposed to compound 1 , revealing a substantial downregulation of genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Additionally, compound 1 induced oxidative stress, leading to elevated reactive oxygen species levels. These multifaceted mechanisms highlight the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents. Natural products remain a proven source of antifungal agents, but few new scaffolds have been introduced in recent decades. We identified a novel polyene macrolide from Kitasatospora melanogena with potent activity against major fungal pathogens. This compound disrupts both the fungal cell wall and membrane while inducing oxidative stress, revealing a multifaceted mechanism of action. summary: This study identified a novel 28-membered polyene macrolide, compound 1, isolated from the soil microbe Kitasatospora melanogena. The compound demonstrated potent antifungal activity against Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus flavus, Candida albicans, and Cryptococcus neoformans, with minimum inhibitory concentrations ranging from 4 to 16 micrograms per milliliter. When exposed to compound 1, Aspergillus fumigatus experienced significant growth reduction and disruption of its cell wall and membrane. A gene-expression analysis analysis revealed that compound 1 decreased activity of genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Additionally, compound 1 induced oxidative stress, leading to elevated levels of reactive oxygen species. These findings suggest that compound 1 may be a valuable lead for the development of novel antifungal agents.  Through the lens of the Patchy Anthropocene, this research highlights the entangled relationships between soil microbes, fungal pathogens, and human health. The discovery of compound 1 from Kitasatospora melanogena underscores the potential for soil microbes to serve as reservoirs for novel antifungal agents, while also underscoring the limitations of current treatments and the urgent need for new solutions.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: This study investigated how doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles (MNPs) influence tomato resistance against fungal pathogens. Three cuboidal CuS MNPs─undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS)─were foliarly applied to Fusarium-infected plants in a greenhouse study. Fe-CuS led to the highest Cu accumulation in leaves─15.7 and 158.4% higher than undoped CuS and Ce-CuS, respectively, likely due to its positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient NPs uptake. Compared to the untreated control, the Fe-CuS foliar application resulted in a 487.7% increase in shoot biomass and a 36.8% reduction in wilt damage through activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling, indicating a dual role of CuS MNPs as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant. Importantly, copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) activation may link Cu homeostasis to stress-induced H2O2 production, indicating a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. These findings underscore the significant potential for CuS MNPs as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, though long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts warrant further evaluation.
summary: Foliar applications of iron-doped copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles (MNPs) to Fusarium-infected tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum) in a greenhouse study resulted in enhanced resistance against fungal pathogens. Three types of cuboidal CuS MNPs were tested: undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS). The iron-doped particles led to the highest accumulation of copper in leaves, likely due to their positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient uptake. This increased copper accumulation was associated with a 487.7% increase in shoot biomass and a 36.8% reduction in wilt damage through activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling. The findings suggest that CuS MNPs can serve as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant, potentially offering an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides. However, further evaluation of the long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts of CuS MNPs is necessary.   The results highlight the complex relationships between copper homeostasis, stress-induced H2O2 production, and nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. The activation of copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) may link copper homeostasis to stress-induced H2O2 production, indicating a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. This study underscores the material entanglements between CuS MNPs, tomato plants, and Fusarium pathogens, revealing the potential for CuS MNPs to both mitigate and exacerbate environmental dependencies.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Chemical fungicides act by targeting specific proteins or pathways, known as modes of action (MoAs). In this study, we established a systematic screening platform using Fusarium graminearum gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify novel antifungal compounds. Target genes corresponding to major fungicide classes were deleted by homologous recombination, and the resulting mutants exhibited altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides compared with the wild-type strain. Deletion of genes encoding known fungicide targets revealed distinct sensitivity profiles, supporting MoA prediction. Using the platform that detects sensitivity differences through OD₆₀₀ changes, we examined a chemical library of 2,704 small molecules and identified 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway. Several of these compounds exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity, underscoring their potential as novel scaffolds for future development. Collectively, this platform provides a robust, mechanism-informed system for antifungal discovery, with broad applicability to synthetic agents, natural products, and biocontrol metabolites. The effectiveness of current fungicides is increasingly limited by resistance, narrow target ranges, and environmental concerns. The framework may also be adapted for use in other areas, including medical and veterinary applications, suggesting potential broader applicability. summary: This paper presents a systematic screening platform for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum. The researchers used a combination of genetic and chemical approaches to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and discover new compounds. They created gene knockout mutants of Fusarium graminearum by deleting genes corresponding to major fungicide classes, and then tested the mutants' sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides. The results showed distinct sensitivity profiles, supporting the prediction of modes of action. A chemical library of 2,704 small molecules was screened, and 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway were identified. These compounds exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity, suggesting their potential as novel scaffolds for future development.  Through this platform, the researchers aim to provide a more systematic way to identify candidate antifungal agents and understand their mechanisms. The framework has potential applications in agriculture, food security, medical, and veterinary fields, and supports the development of more sustainable and long-term disease management strategies. The emphasis on exploring new molecular scaffolds reveals the tension between the need for novel antifungal compounds and the limitations of current fungicides, which are increasingly limited by resistance, narrow target ranges, and environmental concerns.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Lipin, a phosphatidic acid phosphatase, catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol, a key step in triacylglycerol (TAG) biosynthesis, and acts as a transcriptional coregulator of lipid metabolism. In this study, the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) was overexpressed in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to evaluate its impact on lipid accumulation under submerged (SmF) and solid-state fermentation (SSF). Under SSF, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia compared to the control strain. Total fatty acid (TFA) content increased by 35.7% in mycelia, while in spores it increased from 10% to 18% of dry cell weight, indicating a substantial enhancement in lipid yield. Fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. RT-qPCR indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 h under SSF, coinciding with upregulation of ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes. These results suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing TAG biosynthesis under SSF for potential industrial lipid production.
summary: This paper reports on a study where the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) was overexpressed in the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to evaluate its impact on lipid accumulation. The results show that under solid-state fermentation, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia compared to the control strain. Total fatty acid content increased by 35.7% in mycelia, while in spores it increased from 10% to 18% of dry cell weight, indicating a substantial enhancement in lipid yield. The fatty acid profiling indicated elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. Real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-quantitative polymerase chain reaction) analysis showed that McLipin expression peaked at 24 hours under solid-state fermentation, coinciding with the increased activity of of several genes involved in lipid metabolism, including ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes. These findings suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing triacylglycerol biosynthesis under solid-state fermentation for potential industrial lipid production. The capacity of Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to accumulate lipids under controlled conditions highlights the potential of this fungus as a resource for industrial applications, where its ability to metabolize diverse materials and adapt to external stresses can be leveraged to produce valuable compounds.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Aspergillus infection poses a major clinical challenge, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, with invasive diseases associated with high mortality. While Aspergillus fumigatus remains the predominant species causing human infections, recent studies highlight the growing clinical significance of lesser-known and cryptic Aspergillus species, which often exhibit reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies. In this study, we analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. A total of 38 Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections were identified, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounting for 77.1% of all isolates. The most frequently recovered species were A. fumigatus sensu stricto (22.9%), A. sydowii (8.7%), A. calidoustus (7.1%), A. nidulans (6.6%), A. tanneri (6.1%), and A. terreus (5.6%). Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). In contrast, PCR sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates by targeting the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rDNA, 81% using the β-tubulin gene, and 68% using the calmodulin gene. The most common underlying clinical conditions among patients were bronchiectasis (35%), chronic granulomatous disease (22%), and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection (17%). Out of 107 patients, eight died (8/107, 7.5%); six of these deaths occurred in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) and two in patients with RAG1 deficiency. Antifungal susceptibility testing showed that olorofim had the lowest minimal inhibitory concentrations across species. In contrast, the activity of triazoles and amphotericin B was variable, particularly against A. tanneri, A. calidoustus, and A. sydowii. The isolates were identified using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry and polymerase chain reaction sequencing targeting the internal transcribed spacer region of rDNA, the β-tubulin gene, and the calmodulin gene. Eight patients died, six of whom had chronic granulomatous disease. The diversity of Aspergillus species and their varying levels of resistance to standard antifungal therapies underscore the challenges of treating these infections. The fact that non-fumigatus and cryptic species account for the majority of isolates suggests that these organisms may play a more significant role in human disease than previously thought.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, has been reported in several fungal species, but its distribution remains unclear. We analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals using HPLC and LC-MS/MS to assess gliotoxin production. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct ETP-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific ETP profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.
summary: This study analyzed 140 clinical fungal isolates from two major hospitals to assess the production of gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine toxin. The isolates came from various species, including Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus flavus, and Aspergillus terreus. The researchers used high-performance liquid chromatography and liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry to detect gliotoxin production in these isolates. Gliotoxin was found to be produced by only Aspergillus fumigatus isolates under multiple culture conditions. In contrast, other fungal species exhibited distinct epipolythiodioxopiperazine-related pathways, such as aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. This research clarifies the species-specific profiles of epipolythiodioxopiperazine toxins and confirms Aspergillus fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the examined isolates.  Through the lens of the Patchy Anthropocene, the production of gliotoxin by Aspergillus fumigatus isolates highlights the complex and entangled relationships between fungal species and human health. While gliotoxin is a pathogenic compound produced by A. fumigatus, it also underscores the potential for fungi to adapt and evolve in response to environmental pressures and human activities.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), together with 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Their structures were determined by extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established by quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, by a comparison of experimental ECD spectra, or by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 rarely contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for 1 and 2 was proposed. Biologically, compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 had cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116 with IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, and 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also showed significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria with MIC values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. Their structure-bioactivity relationship was also discussed.
summary: The research describes the isolation and characterization of 21 decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids from a marine-derived fungus, Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. These compounds were identified through extensive spectroscopic analysis and quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism spectra.   Compound 1, which contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system, was found to have a plausible biosynthetic pathway proposed.   Biological assays revealed that certain compounds showed toxicity to cells against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116, with IC50 values ranging from 7.3-79.3 μM. Additionally, some compounds demonstrated significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria, with minimum inhibitory concentration values ranging from 1.6-13.0 μg/mL.    the complex interplay between the bioactivity of these compounds and their structure, underscoring the importance of further research into the biosynthetic pathways and potential applications of these marine-derived alkaloids. The findings also underscore the material entanglement between human health, bacterial pathogens, and the marine ecosystem, where a fungus isolated from the ocean can produce compounds with potential medicinal properties.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Mold identification in clinical diagnostics is traditionally labor-intensive and is dependent on expert interpretation. MoldVision is a deep-learning approach that uses smartphone images of mold cultures to automate identification. We analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp. (with A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. Daily images were captured from the top and bottom of culture plates over 5 days using a standardized smartphone setup, generating over 4,000 images. We trained three variations of Visual Geometry Group 16 (VGG16) convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and benchmarked the best-performing model (VGG16 with dual classification heads) against LightGBM models trained on pre-extracted features and human expert assessments at various time points. The best-performing VGG16 model achieved a mean (SD) AUROC of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species. Here, the performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. was best (AUROC of 99.9% ± 0.1%, fivefold cross-validation mean and SD). Regarding the evaluations over time, early-stage classification (days 1–2) was challenging (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5% across all species) but improved significantly on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8% across all species). Compared to experts, MoldVision consistently showed superior performance, particularly in mature cultures, detecting subtle morphological features earlier and more accurately. Our results demonstrate that CNNs integrated with low-cost smartphone imaging can reliably classify mold species in routine diagnostics, outperforming human experts in many cases. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, especially in resource-limited settings. summary: This study analyzed the performance of a smartphone-based imaging system combined with a convolutional neural network in identifying mold species from clinical isolates. The researchers trained three variations of the VGG16 convolutional neural network on over 4,000 images of mold cultures from four common genera: Penicillium, Aspergillus, Fusarium, and Cladosporium. The best-performing model achieved a mean area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 92.7% and sensitivity of 68.7% across all species, with the highest performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. (area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 99.9%). The convolutional neural network showed significant improvement in early-stage classification, from 38.8% F1-score on days 1-2 to 92.1% on days 3-5. Compared to human experts, the convolutional neural network consistently showed superior performance, particularly in mature cultures, detecting subtle morphological features earlier and more accurately. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, especially in resource-limited settings.  The capacity of convolutional neural networks to reliably classify mold species in routine diagnostics highlights the tension between the need for expert interpretation and the potential of machine learning to automate identification. The same technology that operates as a threat to human expertise can also be a resource, offering a practical solution for laboratories in resource-limited settings.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Nitric oxide (NO) is an important biological signaling molecule. S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR), a master regulator of NO signaling, regulates various biological processes. However, little is known about the role of GSNOR in Aspergillus flavus. Here, we identified a gene encoding GSNOR in this aflatoxigenic fungus and demonstrated that GSNOR shows activity during the critical life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. We found that GSNOR plays a crucial role in NO homeostasis, as GSNOR deletion resulted in significantly elevated NO levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous NO stress. GSNOR also participated in multiple biological processes in A. flavus; for that, GSNOR deletion impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, decreased conidiogenesis and sclerotial development, attenuated virulence on kernels, and notably decreased aflatoxin production. Furthermore, we demonstrated that GSNOR is important for reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance, as its deletion significantly elevated mycelial ROS levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. Our findings indicate that GSNOR is crucial for maintaining both NO homeostasis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance and plays an essential role in fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis. summary: This study identified a gene encoding S-nitrosoglutathione reductase in the aflatoxigenic fungus Aspergillus flavus and demonstrated its activity during key life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. The deletion of GSNOR resulted in significantly elevated nitric oxide levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous nitric oxide stress. Furthermore, GSNOR deletion impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, decreased conidiogenesis and sclerotial development, attenuated disease-causing ability on kernels, and notably decreased aflatoxin production in A. flavus. Additionally, the study found that GSNOR deletion significantly elevated mycelial reactive oxygen species levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. The results suggest that GSNOR plays a crucial role in maintaining both nitric oxide homeostasis and reactive oxygen species balance, and is essential for fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis in A. flavus. As Aspergillus flavus is a notorious saprophytic filamentous fungus with carcinogenic aflatoxin production posing serious threats to food safety and human health, targeting components in the nitric oxide signaling pathway, such as GSNOR, could be a novel strategy for aflatoxin contamination prevention and control. The capacity of GSNOR to regulate both nitric oxide homeostasis and reactive oxygen species balance reveals a complex interplay between these signaling molecules in the life cycle of A. flavus, where a pathogen is also a resource for industrial control.
